item.title: Java arrays [Tutorial]
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Vira_, post:1, topic:288265”] int[] anArray; anArray = new int[5] [/quote]

That array can hold 6 values, not 5:

You are confusing the indexes. That array, instantiated with a length of 5 can hold 5 values, with the indexes 0 - 4 (since the first index is 0), if you tried index 5 (which would be the sixth value) you would get an array out of bounds exception.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“primadude, post:1, topic:288871”][quote author=Vira_ link=topic=381102.msg2863988#msg2863988 date=1247344948]

[code]int[] anArray;

anArray = new int[5][/code]

You length of this array is 5, this means it can only hold 5 single value types. [/quote]

That array can hold 6 values, not 5:

[code]int[] anArray;

anArray = new int[5];
anArray[0] = 0;
anArray[1] = 1;
anArray[2] = 2;
anArray[3] = 3;
anArray[4] = 4;
anArray[5] = 5;[/code][/quote]no

system.out.println( + anArray[0]); system.out.println( + anArray[1]); system.out.println( + anArray[2]); system.out.println( + anArray[3]); system.out.println( + anArray[4]);

won’t give you “Hello how are you today!”, itll give you:
Hello
how
are
you
today!
[/quote]

its adding the array’s content to nothing, (which is what T4_ said), and printIn isnt a real method[/quote]
It’s system.out.println, A.K.A system.out.printLn

item.title: Java arrays [Tutorial]
item.dc:creator: @Vira Vira_
item.description:
@Vira wrote:

Okay, well I’ve been studying Java arrays a little more lately as I did forget a little about them, so far I have been learning the basics that I already know, I just want to clarify that I’m doing the correct thing.

So I will be learning you about the Java array, let’s begin.

An array is a container object that holds a fixed number of values in a single type, you can change the length of the array when it is created, you can create an array by doing so.

[code]int[] anArray;

anArray = new int[5][/code]

You length of this array is 5, this means it can only hold 5 single value types. to use this as a program you can do this.

[code]class array {
public static void demo[String[] args) {
int[] anArray;

	anArray = new int[5];

	anArray[0] = 4;
	anArray[1] = 6;
	anArray[2] = 8;
	anArray[3] = 10;
	anArray[4] = 12;

	system.out.printIn("2 and 2 is:" + anArray[0]);
	system.out.printIn("4 and 2 is:" + anArray[1]);
	system.out.printIn("6 and 2 is:" + anArray[2]);
	system.out.printIn("8 and 2 is:" + anArray[3]);
	system.out.printIn("10 and 2 is:" + anArray[4]);
}

}[/code]

That was just a short example of how Java arrays can be used.

You can use various other type of arrays, here’s a few.

byte[] = anArray;

short[] = anArray;

long[] = anArray;

float[] = anArray;

double[] = anArray;

boolean[] = anArray;

char[] = anArray;

String[] = anArray;[/code]

These can all be used differently, here's a short example of the String.

[code]class array {
	public static void demo[String[] args) {
		String[] anArray;

		anArray = new String[5];

		anArray[0] = "Hello";
		anArray[1] = "how";
		anArray[2] = "are";
		anArray[3] = "you";
		anArray[4] = "today!";

		system.out.printIn( + anArray[0]);
		system.out.printIn( + anArray[1]);
		system.out.printIn( + anArray[2]);
		system.out.printIn( + anArray[3]);
		system.out.printIn( + anArray[4]);
	}
}[/code]

Output for this program is:

<blockquote>Hello how are you today!</blockquote>

[b]Something new[/b]
I just love this, I find it very interesting

[code]class ArrayCopy {
    public static void demo(String[] args) {
        char[] copyFrom = { 'R', 'a', 'c', 'e', 'i', 'n', 'g', };
        char[] copyTo = new char[4];

        System.arraycopy(copyFrom, 0, copyTo, 0, 4);
        System.out.println(new String(copyTo));
    }
}

Output: Race

Well, you learn something every day huh?

There aren’t many tutorial here, so please be kind, I only been learning it for a few days.

Read full topic
